Sometimes people mistake the salad bowl for a lawless place of disorganized and mismatched ingredients, chopped up and thrown in  dried cranberries on top of pumpkin seeds on top of soggy corn  which offends even me, who stakes no strong claim to her chef bona fides. A salad nonetheless requires a bit of cheffing, a little experienced attention paid to balance, texture and restraint. Not everything tastes better with bacon bits scattered on top.

title: Five Horror Movies to Stream Now
description: Each month, were recommending five recent horror movies available to stream. Find more genre suggestions and other ways to navigate the streaming services at What to Watch.

title: Did You See What the Liberian Olympic Team Is Wearing?
description: You might have missed it, but look again. They want to change the Olympic fashion game.

title: Some Florida Hospitals Have More Covid Patients Than Ever Before
description: MIAMI  A month ago, the number of Covid-19 patients admitted at two University of Florida hospitals in Jacksonville was down to 14. Now more than 140 people are hospitalized with the coronavirus, a tenfold increase over five weeks  and the highest number of Covid-19 patients this system has seen during the pandemic.

title: How to Calm Your Climate Anxiety
description: Three years ago, after the Woolsey Fire, 53-year-old Greg Kochanowski returned to the Santa Monica Mountains and drove past his own street without recognizing it.

title: Vladimir Menshov, Surprise Russian Oscar Winner, Dies at 81
description: Vladimir Menshov, a prolific Soviet actor and director whose film Moscow Does Not Believe in Tears won the Academy Award in 1980 for best foreign-language film, surprising the many American critics who had panned it, died on July 5 in a hospital in Moscow. He was 81.

title: The Best of Late Night This Week
description: The late-night hosts had no shortage of topics to riff on this week including the Summer Olympics and Jeff Bezoss trip to space.

title: Three-on-Three Basketball at the Olympics: What to Watch For
description: Eighty-five years after basketballs debut in the Olympics, at the 1936 Berlin Games, a twist on the sport makes its Olympic debut in Tokyo. Three-on-three basketball, or 3x3 as the sports world governing body refers to it, promises a faster version than the traditional form.

title: Even the Sheet Cakes Are Bigger in Texas
description: When Michelle Lopez immigrated to Houston from Manila as a teenager, her familys new neighbors all dropped off the same welcome dessert: Texas sheet cake.

title: Ted Lasso Season 2 Premiere Recap: A New Foil for Ted
description: So here we are. Relegation.

title: Are Fitness Buffs Going Back to the Gym?
description: The 5:30 a.m. alarm to hit the spin class. The interminable waits for the ab-crunch machine. The masses of sweating bodies huffing and puffing just feet away, followed by the hurried shower and the wet-haired hustle to the office before the boss arrives.

title: Its a Grizzly Bear Survival Program. For Grizzly Bears.
description: One morning in mid-July, Lana M. Ciarniello, a bear biologist in British Columbia, caught a flight from Vancouver Island, where she lives, to a wildlife sanctuary in the northwestern part of the province to meet two baby grizzlies, the newest subjects in an unusual study she is conducting.

title: Lil Nas X and Jack Harlows Prison Break, and 13 More New Songs
description: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the weeks most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

title: Wonking Out: What Inflation Risks and My Intermittent Fasting Have in Common
description: This article is a wonky edition of Paul Krugmans free newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it.

title: Biden hits the campaign trail for the first time as president, backing Terry McAuliffe for Virginia governor.
description: President Biden made a gleeful return to the campaign trail on Friday evening, joining former Gov. Terry McAuliffe of Virginia, who is seeking to regain his old job in November, for his first campaign event since his inauguration.

title: Make a Splash: 8 Summer Picture Books Take You to the Water
description: CHOICESWritten and illustrated by Roozeboos

title: Arturo Schwarz, Refugee Who Became a Surrealism Tycoon, Dies at 97
description: Growing up in the 1930s and 40s in the cosmopolitan port city of Alexandria, Egypt, Arturo Schwarz idolized European intellectuals.

title: How to Make Brown-Butter Buffalo Sauce
description: Eric Kim, a writer for New York Times Cooking, demonstrates his recipe.

title: Suspect Tries to Compare Capitol Riot to Last Years Violence in Portland, Ore.
description: The comparison has become a staple among right-wing figures in the news media and Republican politicians: The attack on the Capitol on Jan. 6 was really no different than the unrest last year that accompanied months of racial justice protests. Any discussion of the first should  out of fairness, they have said  make reference to the second.

title: Naomi Osaka lights the Olympic cauldron to cap the opening ceremony.
description: TOKYO  An Olympic opening ceremony with all the usual pomp and tradition played out Friday night in Tokyo in front of a nearly empty stadium.

title: Ugandan weight lifter who went missing in Japan returns home.
description: A weight lifter who went missing in Japan this month as he sought to qualify for the Tokyo Olympics has returned to Uganda and will be interrogated by police, authorities said on Friday  a week after his disappearance prompted international news headlines and drew mixed reactions from around the country.

title: We Need a New Term for Video Games
description: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Jerusalem Demsas
description: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like todays episode with Jerusalem Demsas. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

title: N.Y.C.s mayor calls for companies to require shots, as national debate over vaccine mandates picks up.
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio urged on Friday that New York Citys private businesses require their workers to get vaccinated against the coronavirus and signaled that he would introduce similar measures for hundreds of thousands of municipal employees.

title: Amazon will investigate gender bias claims in its cloud division.
description: Amazon has hired a law firm to investigate claims of widespread gender discrimination in part of its cloud computing division, the company said in an email to employees late last week.

title: Monsoon Season Drenches American Southwest
description: The heavy rain provided relief to parts of the region that have been battling drought. However, the storms came with life-threatening flash floods and lightning in places like Scottsdale, Ariz.

title: A Heartbreaking Novel About Mothers, Daughters and Secrets
description: The latest pick for Group Text, our monthly column for readers and book clubs, is Esther Freud's I Couldnt Love You More, a novel about three generations of women grappling with secrets, shame and an inexorable bond. Elisabeth Egan, an editor at the Book Review and the brains behind Group Text, talks about the novel on this weeks podcast.

title: Delays, More Masks and Mandatory Shots: Virus Surge Disrupts Office-Return Plans
description: Several hospital systems that previously held off making vaccines mandatory for health care workers are now willing to do so. Google employees in California who have voluntarily returned to the office are again wearing masks indoors. Goldman Sachs is considering whether to reinstitute testing for fully vaccinated employees in the companys New York City offices, according to a person familiar with the situation who spoke on the condition of anonymity because nothing had been decided. And on Monday, Apple told its work force that it would push back its return-to-office date from September to October.

title: The European Unions drug regulator authorizes the Moderna vaccine for children 12 and older.
description: The European Medicines Agency, the European Unions main drug regulator, on Friday authorized the use of Modernas Covid vaccine for children age 12 and older, clearing the way for final approval by the bloc.

title: Asian Composers Reflect on Careers in Western Classical Music
description: Asian composers who write in Western classical musical forms, like symphonies and operas, tend to have a few things in common. Many learned European styles from an early age, and finished their studies at conservatories there or in the United States. And many later found themselves relegated to programming ghettos like Lunar New Year concerts. (One recent study found that works by Asian composers make up only about 2 percent of American orchestral performances planned for the coming season.)

title: What to Do About Climate Despair
description: The antidote for anxiety is meaningful action.

title: The Olympics Are Great for Streaming. But Is Streaming Great for NBC?
description: The Olympics almost seem like they were designed for the streaming era.

title: Persuasion vs. Coercion: Vaccine Debate in Europe Heats Up
description: PARIS  As Europe and the United States scramble to find an appropriate balance between curbing the Delta variant of the coronavirus and curbing personal freedom, President Emmanuel Macron has led the way down a narrow path combining limited compulsion to get vaccinated with widespread coercion.

title: The Weekender
description: Juno Temple finds acclaim in Ted Lasso. Also in this edition: portraits of New York City service workers, and the fate of IBMs Watson supercomputer.

title: The Walls Close In
description: Stories of people who find themselves stuck in small spaces  an elevator, an attic, an orchestra pit  trying to make sense of their new surroundings.

title: What Makes Elon Musk Different
description: LIFTOFF Elon Musk and the Desperate Early Days that Launched SpaceXBy Eric Berger

title: New in Paperback: Transcendent Kingdom and Agent Sonya
description: TRANSCENDENT KINGDOM, by Yaa Gyasi. (Vintage, 304 pp., $16.) Gyasis second novel trades the blazing brilliance of her first, Homegoing, for a more granular type of glory, Nell Freudenberger wrote in her review. The transcendent kingdom of the title is the primal connection a Ghanaian American neuroscience graduate student and her depressive, religious, immigrant mother maintain as they weather the racism that follows them everywhere.

title: Enlist Trump Against Vaccine Hesitancy
description: To the Editor:

title: A Celebration of Life, a Note of Unease and  Commercials
description: The Olympics opening ceremony is always a real-time visual puzzle, full of abstract imagery and figurative dance saying something  I guess  about global ideals and national character. But you did not need a decoder ring to tease out the symbolism of the restrained pageant that began the Tokyo Games.

title: The Return of the Cannes Film Festival
description: For two weeks in the south of France, you can enter the high holy temple of cinema: the Cannes Film Festival. This is the place where red carpet moments are made, where tuxedos are mandatory and where the audience will stand and clap for a full nine minutes. The celluloid soiree returned this July after last years cancellation because of the pandemic.

title: In the Capitol, the Delta Variant Spreads Worry and Partisanship
description: WASHINGTON  Breakthrough coronavirus cases have emerged in multiple offices in Congress, including the speakers. The line for in-house testing snakes through a long corridor and into a visitors center atrium. The Capitols doctor has warned of the possible return of a mask mandate.

title: Janet Yellen warns Congress that failing to act on the debt limit risks irreparable economic harm.
description: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen warned Congress on Friday that the U.S. economy faced irreparable harm if lawmakers failed to raise or suspend the nations borrowing cap and that the Treasury Department would begin taking extraordinary measures to avoid breaching the so-called debt limit.

title: Its Opening Day at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau
description: Even before the Manhattan Marriage Bureau in Lower Manhattan reopened on Friday for the first time since closing 15 months ago because of the pandemic, the team manager there, Michael McSweeney, said he expected a decent-size, noisy crowd.

title: G.M. issues a new recall of Chevrolet Bolts over a battery fire hazard.
description: General Motors is recalling nearly 51,000 Chevrolet electric cars in the United States whose battery modules have been found to be at risk of catching fire.

title: Some famous American faces were missing from the parade of nations.
description: The opening ceremony was held Friday in Tokyo, but Team U.S.A., led by the flag-bearers Sue Bird and Eddy Alvarez, was missing some famous American faces.

title: Missouris Medicaid Expansion Is On Again
description: The Missouri Supreme Court has cleared the way for the Medicaid expansion to go forward there, ruling unanimously Thursday that the state legislature must fund the new program. The Obamacare program is expected to bring coverage to approximately 275,000 low-income people.

title: America Had Residential Schools, Too
description: Hi everyone, we hope wherever you are, its not too hot (or, at least, that you have somewhere cool to go). This week in the newsletter, were following up on an episode you keep writing in to ask about. Then, we go deeper on a claim made by Facebook in Tuesdays episode and share with you a special show for your weekend listening.

title: Russia Signs Deal With Dubai Logistics Company to Navigate Thawing Arctic
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia  A Russian venture that seeks to take advantage of climate change in the Far North won a key commercial backer Friday when DP World, the gigantic Dubai-based logistics and ports company, signed a deal to help manage operations along sea lanes in the thawing Arctic Ocean.

title: Its a wake-up call, U.S. soccer coach says of loss to Sweden.
description: TOKYO  There are plenty of words to describe the usual mood of the U.S. womens soccer team: competitive, demanding, confident, fun.

title: Im Lucky to Be Here
description: TOKYO  Norie Kosaka knew better than to get her hopes up. A volunteer at the Olympic Games, she had been assigned to work at the opening ceremony on Friday night and naturally assumed she would be one of the workers placed outside Olympic Stadium or tucked into some faraway corridor.

title: For Republicans, Deep Wounds Fuel Resistance to Bolstering the I.R.S.
description: WASHINGTON  A plan by Democrats to pay for infrastructure investments by beefing up the Internal Revenue Service to catch tax evaders has resurfaced old resentments for Republicans, whose distrust of the agency has simmered for years, erasing hopes of a bipartisan legislative accord built on narrowing the so-called tax gap.

title: Love Letter: Redefining a Long-Term Hookup
description: Although the allure of a casual encounter often hangs on the notion of a carefree entanglement, there are actually some rules when it comes to hooking up. Top of the list is keeping your involvement brief.

title: France Adopts Laws to Combat Terrorism, but Critics Call Them Overreaching
description: PARIS  French lawmakers have adopted two bills the government says will strengthen its ability to fight terrorism and Islamist extremism following a series of attacks that have hardened feelings of insecurity ahead of next years presidential election.

title: Federal efforts to stave off an eviction crisis gain some momentum.
description: The Biden administrations effort to head off a crisis when the federal moratorium on evictions expires at the end of the month is gaining modest momentum, with 290,000 tenants receiving $1.5 billion in pandemic relief in June, according to new Treasury Department statistics.

title: How Drug Users Developed a Key Approach to Fighting Covid
description: When I was using heroin in New York City in 1986, half of all the people in the city who injected drugs were H.I.V.-positive. When a friend taught me to run bleach through my syringe at least twice and then rinse twice with water before injecting, she most likely saved my life.

title: Bulgogi, Any Way You Slice It
description: In a decades-old spiral-bound police community cookbook, Songza Parks recipe for BUL KOGI (Barbecued Beef) calls for two pounds of sirloin steak that you have to slice very thin on the bias before scoring each piece with an X. In 1965, when Ms. Park immigrated to the United States from South Korea, she had no access to Korean grocery stores, where today entire cases are dedicated to presliced meat often labeled bulgogi beef.

title: When Euphemisms (but Never Sharks) Attack
description: Shark scientists have been exhorting the public to call human-shark interactions something other than shark attacks, preferring less pejorative terms like shark encounters. The scientists emphasize that humans tend to be to blame for shark injuries  stepping accidentally on small sharks, which snap back; swimming in murky water, venturing too close.

title: Your Flight Has Been Canceled or Delayed. What Should You Do?
description: Carolina Contreras, a 34-year-old business owner who flies frequently between New York and Santo Domingo, in the Dominican Republic, has been using JetBlue exclusively for her trips for almost a decade without a problem. But on her last two flights, she said her flights were delayed for hours; one was pushed back six times.

title: U.S. Strikes Taliban Targets in a Show of Force in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  U.S. military aircraft struck a number of Taliban positions this week in support of faltering Afghan government forces, in one of the first significant American reactions to the insurgents blistering advance across Afghanistan as U.S. troops withdraw.

title: Bruce Kirby, Who Transformed Sailing With a Doodle, Dies at 92
description: Bruce Kirby, a Canadian-born journalist, Olympic sailor and self-taught naval architect whose design for a lightweight fiberglass dinghy, originally sketched on a piece of yellow legal paper, changed the face of sailing, died on Monday at his home in the village of Rowayton in Norwalk, Conn. He was 92.

title: Attorney General Announces Crackdown on Gun Trafficking
description: Attorney General Merrick B. Garland said the Justice Department would launch five federal strike forces aimed at disrupting illegal gun trafficking networks, part of a larger plan to reduce gun violence.

title: Live Webinar: Using Visual Media From The Times to Engage Students
description: In addition to articles, The New York Times offers photographs, illustrations, graphics, videos and virtual reality films that are accessible to learners of all levels. Every school day, The Learning Network uses this rich collection of visuals to create new teaching resources that help educators bring the world to their classrooms.

title: Opening Ceremony Photos: Naomi Osaka, a Drone Globe and a Lot of Empty Seats
description: Japan welcomed the world to the Olympic Games on Friday night. But few people were there to witness the celebration.

title: Live Webinar: An Introduction to The Learning Network
description: The Learning Network publishes nearly 1,000 teaching resources each school year, all based on New York Times content  articles, essays, images, videos, graphics and podcasts. Educators across the globe use our resources to connect students to the world, give them a voice, strengthen literacy skills, and promote critical and creative thinking.

title: New Zealand Pauses Quarantine-Free Travel With Australia
description: Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern of New Zealand announced a pause on quarantine-free travel from Australia for at least eight weeks, as Australia battles a surge of coronavirus cases caused by the Delta variant.

title: Comfort Viewing: 3 Reasons I Love Community
description: In the early days of the pandemic, when everyone was bored at home, I took an extremely comprehensive online personality quiz designed to determine your similarity to more than 1,600 fictional characters from TV, literature and film. My closest counterpart, with a 96 percent match, was Jeff Winger, the charismatic lead character played by Joel McHale on NBCs cult sitcom Community.

title: An insiders view of the opening ceremony: bored guards, locked turnstiles and empty seats.
description: I walked all the way around the main concourse ahead of the show and what did I see? Virtually nothing!

title: Twenty-Five
description: To commemorate the shows 25th year, an episode about people who were born the year This American Life went on the air.

title: U.S. Delegation Is Safe After Reported Shooting in Haiti, White House Says
description: The White Houses press secretary, Jen Psaki, confirmed that the U.S. delegation attending former Haitian President Jovenel Moses funeral was safe after reports of gunfire near the venue.

title: What to Do This Weekend
description: Welcome. If its tomato season where you are, its a good weekend to make Melissa Clarks easy tomato sandwich, which she recommends eating over the sink (to catch the juices). In fact, weve got a whole slew of tomato recipes to put your market haul to good, delicious use. What are you waiting for?

title: How to Make Fast, Easy Skewers on the Grill
description: Its one of the most elemental cooking techniques: impaling food on a skewer or a stick and cooking it over an open fire.

title: Tony Podesta is hired to lobby by Huawei and a Bulgarian energy company.
description: WASHINGTON  The Chinese telecommunications giant Huawei has hired the veteran Democratic lobbyist Tony Podesta as part of an expanded campaign to improve relations with the Biden administration.

title: Why Im Sure Trump Will Run for President in 2024
description: To write three books in four years about Donald Trump has been an immersion into his obsessions and fixations. This is why I know the obvious: Donald Trump will run for president again.

title: Israeli Data Suggests Possible Waning in Effectiveness of Pfizer Vaccine
description: As Israel struggles with a new surge of coronavirus cases, its health ministry reported on Thursday that although effectiveness of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine remains high against severe illness, its protection against infection by the coronavirus may have diminished significantly compared with this winter and early spring.

title: Laura Foreman, Reporter Whose Romance Became a Scandal, Dies at 76
description: Laura Foreman, a reporter for The Philadelphia Inquirer in the 1970s, was surely not the first journalist to become romantically involved with a source. But she was among the first to have that romance, with a powerful politician, blow up into a public scandal.

title: Thomas Barrack, Trumps friend and fund-raiser, is freed on $250 million bond.
description: WASHINGTON  Thomas J. Barrack Jr., a longtime Trump fund-raiser and friend, has reached an agreement with federal prosecutors to be released on $250 million bond while awaiting trial on charges that he illegally lobbied the U.S. government on behalf of leaders in the United Arab Emirates.

title: Alice Clark Brown, Black Star in a White Circus, Dies at 68
description: As a young girl in Chicago in the late 1950s, Alice Clark Brown was entranced by a television show called Circus Boy, especially the opening montage, in which a character named Corky rides a baby elephant.

title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: The opening ceremony of the Olympics today kicked off the delayed Summer Games in Tokyo. For insight into how the pandemic is changing every aspect of competition this year, I checked in with our colleague Andrew Keh, a sports reporter whos covering the Olympics from Japan.

title: Do I Still Have to Take My Hat Off for Dinner?
description: As Jeff Bezos proved when he donned a cowboy hat for his first Blue Origin trip, hats are definitely the statement pieces of the moment  for good or ill.

title: Italy Will Require Proof of Vaccination for Public Events
description: The Italian government announced that it would now require people to show a so-called green pass or proof of vaccination in order to participate in a broad range of social activities, including indoor dining.

title: Bust of Klan Leader Removed From Tennessee State Capitol
description: After years of protests, the bust of Nathan Bedford Forrest, the slave trader, Confederate general and early Ku Klux Klan leader, was removed from the State Capitol in Nashville on Friday and sent to the Tennessee State Museum, state officials said.

title: N.F.L. Sets Stiff Penalties for the Unvaccinated, Jolting Teams
description: Throughout the off-season, the N.F.L. had stopped short of requiring that its players and other team personnel receive a Covid-19 vaccination, instead strongly encouraging inoculation.

title: In London, a Taiwanese Feast With Fortune-Telling Buns
description: Shing Tat Chung and Erchen Chang, the husband-and-wife duo behind Londons beloved Bao restaurants, as well as Xu Teahouse & Restaurant, met while studying at Londons Slade School of Fine Art. And when Chang briefly returned to her home country of Taiwan after graduation, Chung and his sister, Wai Ting Chung, now the couples business partner, whod both grown up in Nottingham  went along. A food-fueled road trip ensued, with the trio taking in Taipei and Yilan in the north, and Kaohsiung, Tainan and Pingtung in the south. They ate everything from braised beef tendon to pigs blood cake  a kind of lollipop made from steamed pork blood and sticky rice coated in peanut powder  and, somewhere along the way, the idea for the Bao brand was born. It takes inspiration from their childhoods, Shing and Wai Tings spent partly at their parents Cantonese restaurants, and from the couples respective artistic sensibilities. Chang studied sculpture and Chung painting, though they both veered toward performance before finishing their degrees. Perhaps that, more than anything else, explains their proclivity for making and presenting food with theatrical flair.

title: Vaccine Mandates, Tokyo Olympics, Cleveland Guardians: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Heres the sign-up.)

title: The U.S. military strikes a Qaeda affiliate in Somalia for the second time in a week.
description: WASHINGTON  The U.S. military conducted a drone strike against Shabab fighters in Somalia on Friday, the second attack in a week since the Biden administration paused such military action against the Qaeda affiliate in East Africa when it took office six months ago.

title: A Border Reopening, at Least One Way, and Some Travel Tips
description: Shortly after the rate of vaccinated people in Canada surpassed the rate in the United States, it was announced that the Canadian border would open next month for all fully vaccinated Americans, not just those with an essential reason to travel.

title: $1 Million in Fines Proposed Over Nitrogen Leak That Killed 6 at Poultry Plant
description: Federal workplace safety officials have proposed nearly $1 million in fines against four companies after finding that they could have prevented the deaths of six workers from a liquid nitrogen leak at a poultry plant in Gainesville, Ga., in January.

title: Purnell Choppin, 91, Dies; Researcher Laid Groundwork for Pandemic Fight
description: Purnell Choppin, whose research on how viruses multiply helped lay the foundation for todays fight against the Covid-19 pandemic, died on July 3 at his home in Washington, one day shy of his 92nd birthday.

title: NBC gives Americans another chance to watch the opening ceremony.
description: If youre in the United States and you werent up at dawn on Friday to watch the opening ceremony from Tokyo, youll have another chance to see the pomp and tradition that played out in front of a nearly empty stadium.

title: Outbreaks of Untreatable, Drug-Resistant Fungus Spread in 2 Cities
description: A deadly, hard-to-treat fungal infection that has been spreading through nursing homes and hospitals across the United States is becoming even more dangerous, according to researchers, who for the first time have identified several cases in which the fungus, Candida auris, was completely impervious to all existing medication.

title: Bust of Klan Leader Removed from Tennessee State Capitol
description: State officials removed the sculpture of confederate general and early Ku Klux Klan leader, Nathan Bedford Forrest, from the State Capitol in Nashville and sent it to the Tennessee State Museum.

title: The F.T.C. asks for an extension to refile its Facebook antitrust suit.
description: The Federal Trade Commission on Friday asked a federal judge to give it more time to refile an antitrust suit against Facebook that is the agencys biggest test in reining in the power of big tech.

title: De Blasio Urges New York Businesses to Require Employee Vaccinations
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio urged on Friday that New York Citys private businesses require their workers to get vaccinated against the coronavirus and signaled that he would introduce similar measures for hundreds of thousands of municipal employees.

title: How the New Capitol Police Chief Wants to Fix an Embattled Force
description: WASHINGTON  J. Thomas Manger, a veteran police chief of departments in the greater Washington region, began work on Friday as chief of the Capitol Police, taking over a nearly 2,000-member force that is in crisis after the Capitol riot on Jan. 6.

title: The Police Believe 98 People Died in the Condo Collapse. One Hasnt Been Found.
description: MIAMI BEACH  The first victim was found in the heap of wreckage just hours after the sudden collapse of a 13-story oceanside condo building. The second body was pulled out a short while later. One after the next, 97 in all, they were located over the past month amid the millions of pounds of mangled steel and concrete.

title: As July Nears Its End, Teams Must Decide What They Are
description: In baseball, the lineups of late July can look like relics within a week. Six years ago on Friday, the Mets used left fielder John Mayberry Jr. as their cleanup hitter against Clayton Kershaw of the Los Angeles Dodgers. Eight days later, Yoenis Cespedes was on his way to New York; the Mets were on their way to the World Series; and Mayberrys career in the majors was over.

title: With the opening ceremony behind them, 23 sports kick off on Saturday.
description: The Olympics really start now. Oh boy, do they start now. A full 23 sports will be in action on Saturday in Tokyo. Eleven gold medals will be awarded.

title: Biden Officials Now Expect Vulnerable Americans to Need Booster Shots
description: WASHINGTON  Biden administration health officials increasingly think that vulnerable populations will need booster shots even as research continues into how long the coronavirus vaccines remain effective.

title: Skilled in Strategy (and Grudges), Top Biden Adviser to Depart White House
description: WASHINGTON  For the past 17 months, since shaking up his campaign after an embarrassing fourth-place finish in the Iowa caucuses, Joseph R. Biden Jr. has relied on Anita Dunn, a veteran Washington consultant, for both guidance and grudge-holding.

title: U.S. broadcast coverage on Saturday includes tennis, swimming and softball.
description: NBC and its sibling networks are covering a full slate of Olympic competitions on Saturday morning, in the early hours in the United States. All times are Eastern.

title: Positive Coronavirus Test Halts Shakespeare in the Park for Third Night
description: The merriment is still on hiatus.

title: Maria Taylor makes her NBC debut during rebroadcast of Olympics opening ceremony.
description: Maria Taylors NBC career began with a surprise appearance from Tokyo before the rebroadcast of the Olympic opening ceremony on Friday evening in the United States.

title: What to Know About the Heat Waves
description: Follow our live coverage of extreme weather and climate change.

title: California is a dominant athletic and cultural force at the Games.
description: You have probably heard it before: If California were its own country, it would rank fifth in an Olympic medal count.

title: After a Republican outcry, Tennessee redirects vaccine outreach to teenagers, shifting it to their parents.
description: Tennessee health officials are resuming several programs to promote vaccinations for public school students, just two weeks after such efforts were halted because Republican elected officials had complained that parents should make the decisions.

title: Blunt End?
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  This is a fun themeless grid from a couple of the youngs (Adam Aaronson and Ricky Cruz, in their first Times collaboration). It introduces itself with a trendy debut, but theres a lot of well-played crunch inside that will appeal to lovers of the classics. I got pretty tangled up in the northeast corner, double-crossed by a slew of misdirects, and Im curious to see what slowed down other solvers.

title: The Olympic flame had a tortuous journey to the ceremony.
description: The Olympic torch has had a lonely journey to the opening ceremony.

title: A Russian shooters slip-up costs her the first gold medal of the Tokyo Olympics.
description: TOKYO  A terrible last shot cost a Russian shooter the first gold medal of the 2020 Olympics.

title: An Olympic beach volleyball match is decided by a Covid infection.
description: The effects of positive coronavirus tests among Olympic athletes began playing out on Saturday, hours after the opening ceremony, as a womens beach volleyball team did not play because of an infection.

title: A typhoon forecast roils the rowing schedule at the Olympics.
description: Tokyo 2020 cant seem to catch a break.

title: Scenes From Americas Largest Wildfire
description: PAISLEY, Ore.  At the eastern edge of the Bootleg Fire on Friday afternoon, there was a surreal sign of the life that once existed in a patch of Oregon forest now turned to ash, smoke and leafless burnt trees: the murmurs of cattle.

title: Quotation of the Day: Virus Surge Complicates Return-to-Office Plans
description: OK, you want me to put my life on the line to come back to the office, which will also decrease my productivity, and youre not giving me any logic on why I actually need to do that?

title: Corrections: July 24, 2021
description: An article on Friday about flooded subways misidentified the nonprofit organization where Bernardo Baranda Seplveda works as a researcher. It is the Institute for Transportation and Development Policy, not the Institute for Transport Development.

title: An Algerian judoka was suspended after withdrawing to avoid meeting an Israeli opponent.
description: The Olympic judo competition found itself mired in a political controversy even before Saturdays start at the Nippon Budokan.

title: The youngest athlete at the Games, a 12-year-old Syrian, goes out in a loss in table tennis.
description: TOKYO  After the final point, after all that she had been through, Hend Zaza, the youngest Olympian at the Tokyo Games, shed a tear.

title: For Yuto Horigome, a Gold Medal Could Change Everything
description: TOKYO  Past the baseball fields at Ojima Komatsugawa Park, which on Friday were full of uniformed boys, is a quiet edge where one of Japans leading Olympians got his start.

title: Fans were barred from the opening ceremony, but a few volunteers were lucky to be here.
description: TOKYO  Norie Kosaka knew better than to get her hopes up. A volunteer at the Games, she had been assigned to work at the opening ceremony on Friday night and assumed she would be one of the workers placed outside Olympic Stadium or tucked into some faraway corridor.

title: Katie Ledeckys Unlikely New Role: Underdog?
description: TOKYO  For nearly a decade, Katie Ledecky has lived a mostly blessed athletic existence.

title: Japans Diverse Olympic Stars Reflect a Country Thats Changing (Slowly)
description: TOKYO  When the Japanese Olympic team marched at the opening ceremony in Tokyo on Friday, towering over the rest of the delegation was the flag-bearer Rui Hachimura, a rising N.B.A. star who was born and raised in Japan.

title: Novak Djokovic wins his first match in punishing heat, after spells of dizziness in the sun.
description: Novak Djokovic resumed his quest for a Golden Slam and the Olympic gold medal Saturday, easily dispatching Hugo Dellien of Bolivia in straight sets.

title: This street skateboarder could deliver Japans first gold.
description: TOKYO  Past the baseball fields at Ojima Komatsugawa Park is a quiet edge where one of Japans leading Olympians got his start.

title: A Rebellion Is Stirring in Boris Johnsons Backyard
description: TUDELEY, England  Hugh Patterson could sense victory when he ran in local elections this year even though this area of rolling countryside, picturesque pubs and pricey rustic homes was a stronghold for his opponent from Prime Minister Boris Johnsons Conservative Party.

title: 3x3 Basketball Is a New Sport, but It Already Has a GOAT
description: TOKYO  It all started with White Men Cant Jump.

description: TOKYO  Nearly everyone in the gymnastics arena  other gymnasts, coaches, arena workers and reporters  stopped what they were doing on Saturday to watch Kohei Uchimura of Japan, considered one of the best male gymnasts ever, perform his horizontal bar routine.

description: A FAREWELL TO GABO AND MERCEDES A Sons Memoir of Gabriel Garca Mrquez and Mercedes BarchaBy Rodrigo Garcia

title: Why America Isnt Getting the Jan. 6 Investigation It Needs
description: Unlike some of my colleagues, I wasnt in the Capitol on Jan. 6, huddling in the hallways as a violent mob rampaged through the building.

title: Are You in an Inter-Intimate Relationship?
description: Hugs. Back rubs. Cuddling. Holding hands.

title: Im Obsessed With Old. The Twist: I Wont See It.
description: Let me say up front that I do not expect to see M. Night Shyamalans latest movie, Old, which arrived in theaters last week, for no other reason than that I am traveling and havent set foot in a theater in almost two years. But in the past few weeks, I have watched its trailer over and over, enthralled by its combination of existential horror and unintended humor. The trailer introduces us to some people who become trapped on a remote beach, where they begin to age at an insanely accelerated pace. Naturally, they try to figure out whats happening, floating theories and freaking out. This being a Shyamalan film, the trailer promises they will spend a lot of time looking confused and concerned  the same facial feat Mark Wahlberg sustained across the running time of The Happening  and yelling at one another, demanding explanations.

title: After New York Tests a New Way of Voting, Other Cities May Do the Same
description: The most high-profile experiment in ranked-choice voting in U.S. history just took place in New York City.

title: Is the Hamptons Party Moving to Springs?
description: Rita Cantina, a festive Mexican restaurant in the Hamptons, has been getting a lot of attention since opening this summer.

title: What Should Happen to Our Data When We Die?
description: The new Anthony Bourdain documentary, Roadrunner, is one of many projects dedicated to the larger-than-life chef, writer and television personality. But the film has drawn outsize attention, in part because of its subtle reliance on artificial intelligence technology.

title: For Older Adults, Home Care Has Become Harder to Find
description: Almost daily, Terry Driscoll drives 40 minutes from her home in Yarmouth Port, Mass., to see her husband, Ken, in his memory care facility.

title: A Long, Joyful Ride
description: We were somewhere above south Louisianas wetlands when the helicopter door popped open.

title: Spain Pledged Citizenship to Sephardic Jews. Now They Feel Betrayed.
description: MADRID  Mara Snchez, a retired mental health therapist in Albuquerque, spent the past four decades tracing her Jewish ancestry from Spain. She created a vast genealogical chart going back nearly 1,100 years, which included three ancestors who were tried in the Spanish Inquisition. Her findings even led her to join a synagogue in the 1980s and to become a practicing Jew.

title: They Were Once Luxury Venues. Now They Are Grim Covid Camps.
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia  The patients sit in packed ambulances before passing through metal gates. Once they are inside, they get a number, like C07-22, a thin blanket and a bedsheet, which is meant to be a mosquito net. Lights shine bright at all hours for constant camera surveillance. Each person is given four bottles of water a day and three small meals.

title: Simone Biles and the Weight of Perfection
description: In the many months leading to this summer, Simone Biles couldnt wait for the Tokyo Olympics.

title: They Waited, They Worried, They Stalled. This Week, They Got the Shot.
description: CHICAGO  They acknowledged that they could have shown up months ago. Many were satisfied that they were finally doing the right thing. A few grumbled that they had little choice.

title: Richard Carapaz of Ecuador prevails in one of the toughest road races in Olympic history.
description: TOKYO  Six days after finishing third in the Tour de France, Richard Carapaz of Ecuador flew to Japan, battled the steamy conditions, pushed his body past exhaustion and won gold in the mens road race on Saturday.

title: He Had a Life Before Death: Remembering Emmett Till for the Child He Was
description: Ollie Gordon was only 7 years old in August 1955, when the life that she shared with three generations of her family, including her cousin Emmett Till, on the South Side of Chicago was overturned.

title: U.S. soccer looks for a rebound against New Zealand.
description: The most remarkable thing about Swedens 3-0 victory over the United States on Wednesday was not the score or the stage but the nature of it: The United States was bullied and bossed around the field for the entire 90 minutes, the kind of beating this team usually delivers rather than receives.

title: Hosting the Olympics Is a Bad Deal
description: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in the news. If you dont already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.

title: U.S. to Announce Troop Drawdown From Iraq, but Little Is Expected to Change
description: BAGHDAD  Iraqs prime minister is heading to Washington this weekend to demand that President Biden withdraw all U.S. combat troops from Iraq, announcing to Iraqi media that the visit would put an end to the presence of combat forces.

title: Amateur Fossil Hunters Make Rare Find in U.K. Using Google Earth
description: LONDON  Millions of years before the Cotswolds, in western England, became a popular vacation destination, romanticized for its ancient woodlands, honey-colored stone villages and medieval abbeys, it was a shallow, warm sea, home to a Jurassic marine ecosystem.

title: A Grandfather Died in Swatting Over His Twitter Handle, Officials Say
description: Mark Herring was at home in Bethpage, Tenn., one night in April 2020 when the police swarmed his house.

title: Cambodia forces people into bleak quarantine camps as an outbreak rages.
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia  The patients sit in packed ambulances before passing through metal gates. Once inside, they get a number, a thin blanket and a bedsheet to use as a mosquito net. Lights shine at all hours for surveillance. Each person is given four bottles of water a day and three small meals.

title: The U.S. soccer team bounced back with a ruthless performance.
description: SAITAMA, Japan  The first game just wasnt good enough, the United States womens soccer players declared.

title: Takato dominates in judo, giving Japan its first gold medal at the Games.
description: Host countries often outperform at the Olympics, and Japan wasted no time capturing its first gold medal at the Tokyo 2020 Games, appropriately enough in judo, a sport the Japanese dominate.

title: The Most Influential Spreader of Coronavirus Misinformation Online
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The article that appeared online on Feb. 9 began with a seemingly innocuous question about the legal definition of vaccines. Then over its next 3,400 words, it declared coronavirus vaccines were a medical fraud and said the injections did not prevent infections, provide immunity or stop transmission of the disease.

title: Skateboarding Arrives at the Olympics: What to Watch For
description: Follow our live coverage of the Olympics.

title: Is That Stroller in the Hallway Really a Safety Hazard?
description: Q: I live on the third floor of a small rent-stabilized walk-up building in the East Village. I have a 1-year-old baby, and have been leaving my stroller at the landing near the bottom of the stairs since he was born. No one complained until a new tenant moved in and told the landlord that the stroller is a tripping hazard. Now the landlord is telling me to move the stroller, but carrying it and my baby up two flights of stairs seems dangerous. What can I do? And what would happen if I ignored the complaints?

title: Bidens Antitrust Team Signals a Big Swing at Corporate Titans
description: WASHINGTON  President Biden has assembled the most aggressive antitrust team in decades, stacking his administration with three legal crusaders as it prepares to take on corporate consolidation and market power with efforts that could include blocking mergers and breaking up big companies.

title: The U.S. womens soccer team files an opening brief in their ongoing equal pay lawsuit.
description: The United States womens soccer team filed its opening brief on Friday in an appeal of their ongoing equal pay lawsuit against the United States Soccer Federation, more than a year after a district court judge dismissed the teams lawsuit.

title: It Is Every Americans Right to Curse the President
description: There is little question that Gary Bundy, a municipal court judge in New Jersey, violated the constitutional rights of Andrea Dick this month by ordering her to remove three banners emblazoned with crude messages about President Biden.

title: American Dysfunction Is the Biggest Barrier to Fighting Covid
description: Globally, the Covid-19 pandemic is a threat because of scarcity of vaccines, with the highly transmissible Delta variant threatening millions around the world who cant get vaccinated.

title: Where People With Disabilities Do Best
description: To the Editor:

title: Apocalypse Right Now
description: WASHINGTON  Holy smokes.

title: A largely maskless, sometimes violent protest against Sydneys lockdown raises fears of superspreading.
description: Defying a statewide stay-at-home order and a worsening local outbreak driven by the Delta variant, 3,500 mostly maskless protesters clashed with police officers on Saturday in downtown Sydney, Australias largest city.

title: Can the Left Regulate Sex?
description: There is a harrowing story in The New Yorker that everyone should grit their teeth and read. Written by Rachel Aviv, it tells the story of how a respected German psychologist named Helmut Kentler decided to foster neglected children with pedophiles, how he ran this experiment with government support for decades after the 1960s, and how it created exactly the kind of hells you would expect.

title: Simone Biles and other teammates cheer on the U.S. mens gymnasts as they advance.
description: TOKYO  Before Saturdays qualification at the Tokyo Games, the men on the U.S. Olympic gymnastics team had their own pep rally.

title: Flood Deaths in China Show Road Risks From Climate Change
description: ZHENGZHOU, China  More than 200 cars were caught in a highway tunnel on Tuesday in central China when record-setting rainfall soaked the area. Torrents of water poured in the tunnels entrances, nearly filling it to the ceiling.

title: In the early medal table, the U.S. is in an unaccustomed spot: at the bottom.
description: Ecuador won a medal on Saturday, the first day medals were awarded at these Summer Games. So did Kosovo, Thailand and Iran. Russia, which isnt even exactly in the Games, won a medal as well.

title: Tokyo Olympics on Saturday: The Games Get Rolling
description: The U.S. womens soccer team found some answers, and a new sport made its Olympic debut.

title: Variety: Split Decisions
description: SPLIT DECISIONS  In the category of practice makes perfect, I have been trying to keep up with Fred Piscops site and solve more of this type of variety puzzle, one which has always been a weak spot for me. Ive always been in the school of old dogs, new tricks, but something else has clicked: I think that my mind is taking a different tactic than it used to and its making me a lot faster.

title: Hospitalized with Covid, a conservative Tennessee radio host shifts his message to urge vaccinations.
description: A conservative radio host in Tennessee who had expressed unwillingness to be vaccinated is now hospitalized with Covid pneumonia and urging his listeners to get the shots.

title: In Charleston, S.C., Saving Historic Homes Means Hoisting Them in the Air
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  Over the course of 150 years, the generations who lived in the handsome house at 17 Logan St. shared a similar experience when walking out of the front door: There were four or five steps to descend, and then it was out onto the flat streets of one of the most beautiful, well-preserved  and flood-prone  cities in the United States.

title: The Right Sandwich for Right Now
description: Hello from New York Times headquarters! Im writing to you from my desk at the office, where I am for the first time since Covid banished me to my home, which I know makes me fortunate. Its sort of thrilling to be here, even though its still empty, and to imagine the newsroom hive buzzing again. But, wow, I felt stress pangs as I left the house. What time would I be getting home? How will I make dinner in the fall when Ill be commuting more often? Were my phone and keys even in my bag?

title: Anti-Lockdown Protesters Clash with Police in Sydney
description: Defying a statewide stay-at-home order, 3,500 mostly maskless protesters marched downtown in Australias largest city, a sometimes violent rally that raised fears an outbreak driven by the Delta variant might worsen.

title: In Hungary, an Embattled L.G.B.T.Q. Community Takes to the Streets
description: BUDAPEST  Defiant, colorful and proud, thousands of Hungarians marched through Budapest on Saturday to support the countrys embattled L.G.B.T.Q. community and to protest the far-right policies of Prime Minister Viktor Orban.

title: Frito-Lay Workers in Kansas Ratify Contract, Ending Strike
description: Hundreds of Frito-Lay employees ratified a contract on Saturday, ending a nearly three-week strike over forced overtime and long hours that many workers said had pushed them past the point of exhaustion, union officials said.

title: U.S. Moves to Drop Cases Against Chinese Researchers Accused of Hiding Military Ties
description: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department moved this week to drop cases that it brought last year against five visiting researchers accused of hiding their ties to Chinas military, prompting questions about the departments efforts to combat Chinese national security threats.

title: Large Covid-related protests hit France, Italy and Australia.
description: Over 160,000 demonstrators took to the streets in France on Saturday to protest the governments Covid-19 health pass policy, with brief clashes between largely unmasked protesters and police officers in Paris followed by wafts of tear gas that were reminiscent of the Yellow Vest turmoil of several years ago.

title: A Romanian Gymnast Chases Her Nations Legacy
description: In October 2014, a video of the Romanian gymnast Larisa Iordache went viral. She was saving Simone Biles from a bee.

title: Camps Have Been Scrambling for Counselors. Some Have Even Closed.
description: BOSTON  Joseph Charnock, like many parents, drew a sigh of relief when he dropped his 12-year-old daughter off for an eight-week session at Camp Quinebarge, on the shores of Lake Winnipesaukee in New Hampshire.

title: Thousands Rally for Equality at Budapest Pride March
description: A Pride celebration in Hungary on Saturday doubled as a protest of Prime Minister Viktor Orbans far-right policies, which have marginalized the L.G.B.T.Q. community.

title: What to Watch as Baseball and Softball Return to the Olympics
description: For the first time in 13 years, baseball and softball will be contested at the Olympics.

title: Star Search
description: SUNDAY PUZZLE  Todays complex creation is a debut from Chandi Deitmer, a social worker in the fields of psychiatry and geriatrics, who got into solving via The Onion, back when you could get a free copy from a box on the corner. (Those were fun puzzles and theres very little digital evidence of them, unfortunately.) She started constructing only a couple of years ago, mainly for independent puzzle publications, which are great venues for constructors and solvers alike  a chance to catch new talent coming up, or solve a puzzle by a constructor you know and like that doesnt go into the Timess rotation. In this case, Ms. Deitmers debut was with The Inkubator; try it here, if youre enamored with todays solve. After all, the title of this puzzle is Star Search!

title: Simone Biles headlines a star-studded lineup.
description: Two words: Simone Biles.

title: Your Guide to Olympics Gymnastics: Floor Exercise
description: Womens gymnastics is a marquee sport at the Summer Olympics, but otherwise doesnt get much attention outside a dedicated group of fans.

title: Heres a photo recap of Day 1 at the Olympics.
description: Twenty-three sports kicked off play on Saturday in Tokyo, including table tennis, gymnastics and swimming. Here are some of the best photos from the New York Times team on the ground.

title: Your Guide to Olympics Gymnastics: Vault
description: Womens gymnastics is a marquee sport at the Summer Olympics, but otherwise doesnt get much attention outside a dedicated group of fans.

title: Your Guide to Olympics Gymnastics: Balance Beam
description: Womens gymnastics is a marquee sport at the Summer Olympics, but otherwise doesnt get much attention outside a dedicated group of fans.

title: Your Guide to Olympics Gymnastics: Uneven Bars
description: Womens gymnastics is a marquee sport at the Summer Olympics, but otherwise doesnt get much attention outside a dedicated group of fans.

title: Katie Ledecky may finally have a true challenger.
description: The U.S. swimmer Katie Ledeckys domination is so routine that her surname has become a verb, synonymous with crushing the competition. For nearly a decade, she has ledeckied away in her specialties  distance swims longer than 400 meters  rarely facing a true challenger and certainly nothing resembling a rival.

title: The diversity of Japans team reflects a country thats changing, slowly.
description: At least 35 members of the 583-strong Japanese Olympic team are multiracial. They are considered medal contenders in tennis and judo and will compete in boxing, sailing, sprinting, rugby and fencing, among other sports.

title: Nyjah Hustons long, strange skateboard trip to the Olympics.
description: LAGUNA BEACH, Calif.  Nyjah Huston was driving his Mercedes coupe well past the speed limit between his $3 million house overlooking the Pacific Ocean and his private indoor skatepark where he was training for the Olympics.

title: Jackie Mason, 93, Dies; Turned Kvetching Into Comedy Gold
description: Jackie Mason, whose staccato, arm-waving delivery and thick Yiddish accent kept the borscht belt style of comedy alive long after the Catskills resorts had shut their doors, and whose career reached new heights in the 1980s with a series of one-man shows on Broadway, died on Saturday in Manhattan. He was 93.

title: The Olympic movement fails in supporting Black women, our columnist writes.
description: For better or worse, the Tokyo Olympics are finally here. And that means an extraordinary burden will fall again on the shoulders of a single group of athletes: Black women.

title: Yuto Horigome wins the first skateboarding medal as Nyjah Huston falters.
description: Skateboardings entry into the Olympics evolved into a tense can-you-top-this exhibition in the mens street competition, as one world-class skateboarder after another did nuanced variations of tricks off the parks biggest feature, a 12-stair drop with three different rails.

title: Rodney Alcala, the Dating Game Serial Killer, Dies
description: Rodney Alcala, who was known as the Dating Game Killer and was convicted in the murders of six women and one girl in the 1970s, died on Saturday at a hospital in Kings County, Calif. He was 77.

title: Heres what to watch for from the U.S. gymnastics team.
description: The first day of womens gymnastics is a marathon: The qualification rounds, which decide which teams and athletes will vie for medals, last about 12 hours.

title: Surfing at the Olympics: What to Watch For
description: The worlds best surfers will be converging at the Olympics for the first time. Theyre poised to put on a good show  as long as the waves cooperate.

title: How to watch in the United States.
description: The first day of womens gymnastics is a marathon: The qualification rounds, which decide which teams and athletes will vie for medals, last about 12 hours.

title: Womens gymnastics kicks off in Tokyo. Follow our live blog here.
description: Follow our live blog coverage of the gymnastics competition here.

title: Heres how to make sense of the womens gymnastics competitions.
description: Womens gymnastics is a marquee sport at the Summer Olympics, but otherwise doesnt get much attention outside a dedicated group of fans.

title: Simone Manuel and the U.S. win bronze in the 4x100-meter freestyle relay.
Chase Kalisz wins the first U.S. gold medal in Tokyo.
description: TOKYO  After an opening day without a medal, the United States swim team got two in the first event of the day on Sunday. By lunchtime, Americans had collected a half dozen at the pool.

title: What is honey used for? In gymnastics, its mostly the men using it.
description: While the women competed in Tokyo, viewers watching NBCs tape-delayed coverage of mens gymnastics might have noticed honey bottles near the parallel bars.

title: No. 1 seed Ashleigh Barty is eliminated from the womens tennis tournament.
description: Naomi Osaka of Japan won her first match as a rare athlete to light an Olympic cauldron, but Ashleigh Barty of Australia is out of the Olympic singles tennis tournament.

title: April Ross and Alix Klineman begin with a win in beach volleyball.
description: TOKYO  April Ross and Alix Klineman, an American power duo in beach volleyball, started their Olympics with a win on Sunday, defeating the Chinese team of Xue Chen and Wang Xinxin, 21-17, 21-19.

title: Corrections: July 25, 2021
description: An article on Page 8 this weekend about a staging of Don Giovanni refers incorrectly to the orchestra MusicAeternas recent activities at the Salzburg Festival in Austria. The ensemble did not play both Mozarts La Clemenza di Tito and Idomeneo; it played only La Clemenza di Tito. The Freiburg Baroque Orchestra performed Idomeneo.

title: Quotation of the Day: Unbowed, Biles Keeps on Rising Five Years Later
description: At the end of the day, Im such a huge athlete, but who am I? If you take off that mask, you know, who will I be? Im still trying to find that out.

title: Bryson DeChambeau and Jon Rahm drop out of golf after testing positive.
description: The mens golf tournament at the Olympics will begin on Thursday without either of the last two U.S. Open winners.

title: An Iranian defector beats an Iranian in taekwondo.
description: In 2016, she became a teenage hero in her home country after becoming the first woman to win an Olympic medal for Iran. On Sunday, Kimia Alizadeh was a defector, part of a refugee team, with a draw pitting her against an Iranian opponent.

title: Australia Dominates Again in the Womens 4x100 Freestyle Relay
description: Australia won the 4x100 freestyle by more than 3 seconds over the United States. Heres the meter-by-meter analysis of how they did it.

title: Simone Biles starts Olympics with a floor exercise that isnt up to her usual standards.
description: Simone Biles usually owns the floor exercise. She has been great in the event ever since she was very young, back when some people mistakenly thought she would end up to be a specialist on the floor and the vault  and never an all-arounder. Those naysayers are probably hiding in a corner now.

title: MyKayla Skinner had a long road to the Olympics.
description: Several months ago, MyKayla Skinner was hospitalized for pneumonia after contracting the coronavirus. Now, her long career  in both elite and college gymnastics  is ending at the Tokyo Games.

title: We Could Not Find a Sign Pointing Us to Home Plates Former Home
description: Dear Diary:

title: The Fisherwomen, Chevron and the Leaking Pipe
description: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

title: Biles launches to top vault spot even without widely anticipated move.
description: Everyone in the sport has been talking about when Simone Biles will attempt her breathtaking Yurchenko double pike vault at the Olympics. Turns out, it wasnt during qualifying. And even without it, she did well enough to slide into first place on the vault after her turn.

title: Sunisa Lees complex bars routine puts her in top spot after her rotation.
description: No one in the world does an uneven bars routine as complex as Sunisa Lees, and she needs a mind-blowing amount of precision to perform it without smacking the bars by mistake and falling  or just falling because she missed grabbing the bars after a release move.

title: Jordan Chiles is having an off day.
description: One question on many gymnastics fans minds was how well Jordan Chiles would fare in qualifications: Would she move on to the all-around or event finals, or would she be shut out because of gymnastics two-per-country rule?

title: The Enduring Whimsy and Wonderment of Eric Carle
description: Ive been looking at a letter from Eric Carle, written in a frail script in 2019, in which he told me that his health was failing. It was the last of many letters, some typed, others handwritten, he had sent me through the years.

title: Homes That Sold for Around $500,000 or Less
description: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

title: Child Tax Credit Payments Have Begun. Should You Opt Out?
description: Millions of families with children have probably noticed that their bank accounts looked a little more flush this month because they received an extra injection of cash from the government  up to $300 for each child.

title: Nancy Mace Called Herself a New Voice for the G.O.P. Then She Pivoted.
description: MOUNT PLEASANT, S.C.  Representative Nancy Mace had just delivered the kind of red-meat remarks that would ordinarily thrill the Republican voters in attendance here on a recent sweltering evening, casually comparing liberal Democrats to terrorists  the Hamas squad, she called them  and railing against their socialist spending plans.

title: Fauci Wants to Make Vaccines for the Next Pandemic Before It Hits
description: In one sense, the world got lucky with the new coronavirus. By sheer chance, scientists just happened to have spent years studying coronaviruses, developing exactly the tools needed to make Covid vaccines as soon as the viruss genetic sequence was published.

title: Facebooks Next Target: The Religious Experience
description: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

title: The Pandemic Ruined Third Grade. Can Summer School Make Up for It?
description: GREENSBORO, N.C.  In second grade, Zion Graham bounded to school. He loved math. His favorite book was about a slow turtle who took all day to get dressed.

title: In Nagorno-Karabakh, Land Mines, Bulldozers and Lingering Tensions
description: KELBAJAR, Azerbaijan  The medieval monastery walls are masked with camouflage netting. Machine-gun nests line the courtyard under a fluttering Russian flag. Cannons mounted on armored vehicles guard the mountainside where tour buses used to park.

title: Oksana Chusovitina, at 46, gets a standing ovation at her last Olympics.
description: After Oksana Chusovitina, a gymnast competing for Uzbekistan, finished her practice session last week here at the Tokyo Games, gymnast after gymnast lined up to pose with her for a selfie. She is royalty in the sport.

title: A Son of Tokyo Wins Skateboardings First Gold
description: TOKYO  With its street-riding roots, youthful vibe and full immersion into culture of all kinds, skateboarding was invited to the Olympics because its global reach could no longer be denied.

title: Meet Olympic Surfings Wave Whisperer
description: ICHINOMIYA, Japan  Surfing is the only event at the Summer Olympics without a precise, predetermined schedule. It might happen today, but maybe not.

title: Vaccines, Tokyo Olympics, Summer Camp: Your Weekend Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: The Week in Business: Rethinking Office Plans
description: A new spike in coronavirus cases, driven by the highly infectious Delta variant, rattled investors and companies last week. On Monday, fear over what a rise in cases, mostly among the unvaccinated, would mean for the global economic recovery drove the worst decline for the S&P 500 in months. But on Tuesday, stocks bounced back. The recent outbreaks are also prompting executives to rethink their plans for reopening offices. Apple, for example, said it would delay its plans to return to the office by at least a month, to Oct. 1 at the earliest. But not all companies have come to the same conclusion. Morgan Stanleys chief legal officer urged the banks outside law firms to call their lawyers back to the office.

title: The Sunday Read: The Little Hedge Fund Taking Down Big Oil
description: The activist investment firm Engine No. 1 had been making the case since December that Americas most iconic oil company needed a directorial shake-up. Their argument was based on the idea that failing to plan for the impact of climate change could spell the demise of a business.

title: A Baseball Nomad Is Still on the Move
description: Edwin Jackson was still in diapers the first time he moved.

title: U.S. mens basketball, looking for a fresh start, loses to France instead.
description: SAITAMA, Japan  The United States mens basketball team fell to France, 83-76, in its opening game of the Olympics on Sunday night at Saitama Super Arena, remaining on unsteady footing after taking a rocky path to Tokyo.

title: German gymnasts are wearing unitards to stand against sexualization.
description: When the four members of the German womens gymnastics team walked onto the competition floor on Sunday evening wearing sparkly ankle-length unitards, they were sending a message that the countrys gymnastics federation has characterized as against sexualization in gymnastics.

title: Require vaccines? In parts of the U.S., even mask mandates are a bridge too far.
description: As the Delta variant of the coronavirus spreads through unvaccinated populations in the United States, many municipalities, colleges and businesses are weighing not only whether to require vaccinations but also whether to reimpose indoor mask mandates.

title: After Two Decades in Music, Yola Expands Her Powers
description: Calculus is hard. Parallel parking is hard. Meeting and working with people who dont look like you  thats a breeze. Its. Not. Hard, the singer and songwriter Yola emphasized during a recent call, clapping her hands in between each word. I literally came from another continent, and remedied it in six months. Even my manager, from remotely in England, found writers of color for me.

title: Naomi Osaka Returns to the Stage, on Her Terms
description: TOKYO  In the early afternoon Sunday, Naomi Osaka walked onto the center court at the Ariake Tennis Park to begin her quest for an Olympic gold medal.

title: Disinformation for Hire, a Shadow Industry, Is Quietly Booming
description: In May, several French and German social media influencers received a strange proposal.

title: Tokyo Olympics on Sunday: Time to Go Big
description: Because holding back now helps nobody.

title: Americas Rugby Sevens Teams Try to Restart Their Prepandemic Roll
description: CHULA VISTA, Calif.  Momentum is a funny thing in sports. It can crystallize seemingly out of nowhere and vanish just as easily.

title: No Longer Hidden Victims, Children Are Dying as Virus Surges in Indonesia
description: Hundreds of children in Indonesia have died from the coronavirus in recent weeks, many of them under age 5, a mortality rate greater than that of any other country and one that challenges the idea that children face minimal risk from Covid-19, doctors say.

title: What to Cook This Week
description: Good morning. Were moving into the slowest of the slow days, deepest summer, everything languid, not much happening at all. Tomatoes are ripening. Corns growing tall. Im getting reports from cookouts and barbecues, clambakes, fish fries, oyster feeds and picnics  all those spirited endeavors we missed last year, sheltering from the pandemic in our pods. I hope your weekend was filled with them, with the joy of gathering with others in the presence of food and drink.

title: How to Reopen a Festival City When a Virus Lurks: Very Anxiously
description: NEW ORLEANS  Virgil Tiller is back to work on Thursday nights, playing his saxophone with the Stooges Brass Band at The Well, a small club located at the edge of the citys Trem neighborhood, about five blocks from the French Quarter.

title: Should Big States Be Broken Up?
description: To the Editor:

title: Why Do Parents Keep Hearing About the Microbiome?
description: Our bodies house an extraordinarily vast collection of bacteria and other microorganisms  so many, in fact, that scientists now estimate there may be just as many bacteria in our bodies as human cells.

title: The Delta Variant Is the Symptom of a Bigger Threat: Vaccine Refusal
description: After an all too brief respite, the United States is again at a crossroads in the pandemic. The number of infections has ticked up  slowly at first, then swiftly  to 51,000 cases per day, on average, more than four times the rate a month ago. The country may again see overflowing hospitals, exhausted health care workers and thousands of needless deaths.

title: For U.S. Lifters, Its Fly, Then Clean and Jerk
description: TOKYO  It is the travel version of a weight lifting attempt: months of preparation, a few moments to set oneself, a brief burst of all-out effort and, hopefully, a winning result.

title: Vaccine Mandate Is Not the Federal Governments Role, Psaki Says
description: Jen Psaki, the White House press secretary, said on Friday that mandating Covid-19 vaccinations was an appropriate decision for private sector companies, institutions and local communities.

title: She celebrated as if she had won a gold. Except she hadnt.
description: It was the crowning achievement of her cycling career. Except it wasnt.

title: Leaders in Cryptocurrency Industry Move to Curb the Highest-Risk Trades
description: Two of the worlds most popular cryptocurrency exchanges announced on Sunday that they would curb a type of high-risk trading that has been blamed in part for sharp fluctuations in the value of Bitcoin and the casino-like atmosphere on such platforms globally.

title: Landslide Kills 9 in Northern India and Destroys Bridge
description: A landslide in northern India caused boulders to tumble down a mountain and strike a vehicle, killing at least nine people, many believed to be tourists, and destroying a bridge.

title: Soccer Team Was Lone Bright Spot in West Bank Village. Virus Took That, Too.
description: WADI AL-NIS, West Bank  The bleachers were mostly empty, the coach was nowhere to be found, and the players were dejected as they suffered another lopsided defeat.

title: Medal ceremonies at Tokyo Games require social distance and limits on not wearing a mask.
description: It is a quintessential Olympic moment. After every event, after the Olympic champions national anthem is played, the winners of the silver and bronze medals are welcomed to the top step of the medals stand. There, they pose  together with the winner  for a photograph.

title: Its not going to be good. Fauci sounds alarm over low vaccination rates fueling Covid surge.
description: Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, President Bidens chief medical adviser, warned on Sunday that the coronavirus pandemic is now going in the wrong direction in the United States because too many Americans are still choosing not to get vaccinated.

title: The Salzburg Festival Opens in Search of Elusive Peace
description: SALZBURG, Austria  What is peace? a singer asks in Latin at the start of Klaus Hubers Quod Est Pax? The orchestra responds with a wandering, spectral sound that underscores the question, as it is asked again and considered from different angles, until the instruments erupt in a disorderly mass as if to answer: Peace is not a pleasant tune.

title: Pelosi Appoints Kinzinger to Panel Scrutinizing Jan. 6
description: WASHINGTON  Speaker Nancy Pelosi on Sunday appointed Representative Adam Kinzinger to the special committee investigating the Jan. 6 riot at the Capitol, adding a second Republican who is a forceful critic of former President Donald J. Trump to the panel.

title: New York Has $2.7 Billion for Rent Relief. Many Have Yet to Receive Aid.
description: When New York launched a sweeping rent relief program in June, the aim was to safeguard the states recovery from the pandemic by keeping tens of thousands of people who fell behind on rent out of financial ruin and in their homes.

title: At Surfings Olympic Debut, Routine Waves and No Regrets
description: ICHINOMIYA, Japan  Like most surfers, Stephanie Gilmore of Australia never expected to see surfing in the Olympics.

title: Bob Moses, Crusader for Civil Rights and Math Education, Dies at 86
description: Bob Moses, a soft-spoken pioneer of the civil rights movement who faced relentless intimidation and brutal violence to register Black voters in Mississippi in the 1960s, and who later started a national organization devoted to teaching math as a means to a more equal society, died on Sunday at his home in Hollywood, Fla. He was 86.

title: Mr. President, Youre Just Plain Wrong on Voter Suppression
description: Before I turn to President Bidens historic failure to protect voting rights, a couple of stipulations must be made.

title: Review: In You Are Here, Dancing and Splashing at Lincoln Center
description: As dance regains its footing in the performing arts world this summer  gradually and with grit and the best of intentions  putting on a show carries a different weight. How exactly must the show go on? Who shares responsibility and who gets the credit? If the past year and a half has taught us anything, its to pay attention to those on the edges, to recalibrate just who and what are essential. Art and artists, certainly. But it takes more than artists to make art happen.

title: Taekwondo Is Path to Medals for Countries That Rarely Get Them
description: TOKYO  In the sand-swept alleys of Niamey, the capital of one of the worlds poorest nations, Niger, they spin kick. In the Azraq refugee camp in Jordan, crowded with Syrians who fled civil war, they scissor kick. And in the slums of Thailand, where martial arts offer a tantalizing path out of poverty, they deliver the chopping ax kick that helps make taekwondo the most explosive of the combat sports.

title: What to watch for in swimming at the Olympics.
description: Like most years, we dive into the Olympics by diving into the pool. Swimming dominates the first week of the games. Expect some familiar faces and some new ones, many of them Americans, on the medals stand.

title: Rescuing Chinas Muzzled Past, One Footnote at a Time
description: For decades, Yu Ruxin, a businessman turned independent historian, scoured used book stalls across China for frayed, yellowing documents about the Cultural Revolution, a decade of mass political upheaval unleashed by Mao Zedong.

title: Your Monday Briefing
description: The Games opened on Friday to a sea of empty seats, and a somber opening ceremony that tried to project a world moving on from the worst of Covid-19. Naomi Osaka, Japans most famous athlete, lit the Olympic caldron.

title: The Great Outdoors Is Giving Way to the Great Indoors
description: MISSOULA, Mont.  I wouldnt go out without an N95 mask, an oncology nurse told me the other day. She wasnt referring to Covid-19 protections. Cases here remain quite low. Im vaccinated. Besides, I wasnt planning to be indoors. It was for the smoke.

title: U.S. General Wont Commit to Ending Airstrikes on Taliban
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The top American general overseeing operations in Afghanistan declined to say Sunday night whether U.S. airstrikes against the Taliban would end Aug. 31, the date previously given by officials as a cutoff for such attacks.

title: Broadcaster Apologizes for Inappropriate Images Aired During Olympic Parade
description: For television broadcasters worldwide, the parade of nations during the opening of the Olympics can be an exercise in diplomacy and global awareness, with media outlets resorting to trivia nuggets, athlete profiles and geopolitical musings to fill airtime.

title: Known for Paradoxes
description: MONDAY PUZZLE  Congratulations to Tommy Pauly, who is making his debut today with this pun-packed Monday puzzle. The theme is a delight, and I enjoyed the slow-motion revealer that started at 1A and ended at the final across clue (68A).

title: U.S. broadcast coverage includes swimming, softball and taekwondo.
description: Here are some highlights of U.S. broadcast coverage for Sunday evening and overnight, including womens swimming, taekwondo and the next game for the seemingly unstoppable softball team. All times are Eastern.

title: In Louisiana, Vaccine Misinformation Has Public Health Workers Feeling Stuck
